title: Ticket #73: Use Daemon() constructor that takes a ClassAd*, not a char*
description:
The Daemon object (condor_daemon_client/daemon.*) has two constructors for initial creation. One takes a ClassAd* for the daemon to contact, the other takes a char * that is the "name". The ClassAd version has lots of smarts built it: it recognizes that a daemon may have multiple addresses (because of GCB) and can intelligently pick between them. The char* version is dumb and just connects up to the hostname/port or sinful string given. Right now this means that the GCB PRIVATE_NETWORK_NAME optimization doesn't work on these connections. It also means that future smarts (say, better handling of multi-homed machines) won't work either. So...

Whenever feasible, we should use the Daemon(ClassAd*,...) constructor, not the Daemon(...,char*,...) constructor.
